WRITING.TEXT:
I might be misreading the hostility this particular post is getting, but just to be claer, I am in non way a Trump supporter, as seems to have be an initial assumption made by aullik.
If true, that would be a pity: I actualy appreciate honest political discussions.
Also, I'm probably not going to offer to upload it here for reasons of privacy, but I actually defend the German labor-management relations system against American cand other misguided critics. I personally believe the German co-determination system is significantly more superior to American labor-management relations.
More specifically related to this particular post, I believe codetermination has a woefully misunderstood ***positive*** consequential impact on Germany's comparative advantage and macroeconomic strength, one manifestation of which is its trade surplus.
It would be a damned shame if the "neoliberals" miss this point as they continue trying to ram the so-called Washington Consensus down the world's throat.

WRITING.TEXT:
Yes, I am not part of an astroturfing campaign.
As I have mentioned to RebasKradd a few times, I generally [and perhaps slightly pretentiously] don't like to engage in many conversations on Reddit. In my experience, there are a lot more trolls commneting than real people interested in genuine dialogue. At times, when I find honest conversation, I reply.
I apologize if my posting activities are kinda confusing; but I promise you, I am posting on my own volition and not part of any nefarious astroturfing campaign.
For the record, I've noticed this subreddit is more substantive and a lot more conversational than most, which I really appreciate. This subreddit defies my general cynicism when it comes to subreddit culture.
EDIT: If anyone here would be interested in a substantive reply or comment on my part, feel free to ask. I love conversation - particularly political conversations.

I would think so. Offset Tillerson's (Exxon and Big Oil's) influence. However, if this campaign gets just enough attention, Elon Musk will probably feel it is in his and his companies' interests to be more outspoken and publicly assertive. Once Elon feels it necessary to be more outspoken and assertive, I believe this campaign should end - otherwise, Elon would lose any leverage he could have gotten from the campaign.
But for the record, I do not see the benefit of Elon leaving an advisory role in the White House. Unless Elon becomes involved with an uprising or revolt of the more 'forward-thinking'' advisers (that'd result in either a coup, Trump being forced to resign, or Trump losing in 2020, all of which I'd support).

I think it's important to keep on emphasizing the fact that Trumpism ***is not*** traditional conservatism. Trumpism is a form of ***right populism*** .
I don't think my friends on the right-of-center would disagree when well-meaning leftists make the mistake of calling Trumpsim conservative.
The above article is yet one more attempt to correct this faulty assumption.
A phenomena that makes this clearer is something that is happening on the most extreme Left: Many well-meaning friends on the purist Left reflexively conflate "populism" with "progressivism" - and this, while appearing to be an innocent mistake, can be ***very, very dangerous***.
At the end of the day, left populism [shares many](https://ideas.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/23/liberals-vs-populists-its-a-long-story/) of the [same fundamental assumptions](http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=30088) behind right populism, and Trumpism represents these [common assumptions](http://www.breitbart.com/2016-presidential-race/2016/06/17/populism-replacing-conservatism-winning/) - namely, ethnicist and other identitarian assumptions couched in paranoia (this is why the alt-right employs traditionally leftist-populist language, and Europe's new socialist politicians employ anti-immigrant messaging). Bernie Sanders [himself gave air to these implicit identitarian assumptions in his critique of open borders](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vf-k6qOfXz0). So this is a problem for both Conservatives and Republicans ***and*** Liberals and Progressives and Democrats to fix.
We need a transpartisan coalition that stands up ***against*** the breakdown of our traditional liberal order (I don't mean "liberal" in the sense that the GOP uses as boogeymen). The reality is, today's brand of populism is a unique threat to any bipartisan and transpartisan consensus, for the very reason that it is left populism and right populism that ***rejects*** the idea of bipartisanship and transpartisanship, and ***rejects*** what movements like NeverTrump stands for.

For the record, I wasn't asking for thought control.
I was just getting frustrated that Turless seemed to ignore that the blog I linked to clearly wasn't meant as an attack on Trump.
What frustrates me is that any critique of *any* right-of-center or conservative position [i.e., Islamophobia] from a left-of-center position is deemed not credible or invalid - even though a very similar critique is held by other conservatives and others on the right. Whether aware of Islamophobia's critics on the conservative right or not, Turless's initial comment seemed to imply that since the link was to a left-of-center perspective (even if it had nothing to do with attacking Trump) and that I myself am left-of-center on many issues, it does not matter that my intention behind posting this article (praise the appointment decision b/c of McMaster's ant-Islamophobia stance) is shared by many conservatives.
That left me to believe that the fact that the critique of Islamophobia came from a left-of-enter perspective invalidated the whole thing in Turless's perspective, which thus means that his main beef with the post is the identity of the poster (me) and the identity of the blogger ('people like me').
He himself wrote that this sub is only meant for right-of-center NeverTrumpers in one of his follow-up comments. So regardless of him trying to say that he separates identity from politics, it sure did seem like he didn't like the identity of those positing the political critique, and attacked the critique based on that identity.
If I remember correctly, that is not the idea behind this sub.

For me, I do attribute many if not most of my political persuasions to a large part of my identity - and I do not believe [or at the very least do not understand] - how anyone else ***does not*** have political persuasions strong enough to form at least part of their identities.
I know you might not care, but I'll offer this as an example: I am an American Jew with grandparents who survived the Holocaust. Their children - my father and uncle - were bullied, harassed, and assaulted almost every single day walking back and forth from school up through high school. Being recent immigrants from Israel, they were targeted based on their immigrant identities. Some of those beatings would have killed them if police had not intervened. And the guys who did these things were thoughtless idiots who would call what they did as "harmless trolling" - because they were taught by subversive "pop" or "alternative" figures that that was "funny," and that "triggering" them will "toughen them" up.
Being vicitimized by Hitler's political project starting at a very early age, my grandmother was emotionally and psychologically stunted from a very young age, and she remained so until her death a few years ago.
As a consequence of her inability to relate to other humans in an emotionally-mature way, or to relate to the world in a psychologically-healthy way, my father and his brother's lives were infested by the shell of a human being Hitler gave them. Whenever I asked why my grandmother called them 24/7, shouted at them, spoke about fake neo-Nazi conspiracies of her neighbors experimenting on her through the walls, etc., my father did his best to explain to me that she was a broken, damaged woman. I then asked my father and my uncle if they believed that their mother loved them, to which they said no. Being young, I was confused, and they tried to explain to me that when someone is broken like that at a young age, they are unable to grow or develop properly - including emotionally and psychologically.
My father and his brother were very important, very formative figures in my life, and I unfortunately lost both at a young age.
I am not trying to tell you a sob story to get you to sympathize with me or whatever. I just want you to know how someone's identity can both ***be*** politicized (by seeing how a mother can mistreat her own sons she could never love, all because she didn't have time to grow into a full human being), and ***political*** (by choosing to turn my own feelings of confusion, frustration, and nostalgia for a family I could never have into a desire to ensure that others can have what I did not).
My personal opposition to President Trump is that he seems to inspire a very similar culture of xenophobia, nativism, and ethno-nationalism that my own family barely survived. And whether he meant to or not, he certainly does not seem to feel the need to temper it. As I [wrote in another comment in this sub before](https://www.reddit.com/r/NeverTrump/comments/5vq4n4/young_white_men_are_being_radicalised_its_time_to/de6bpwy/?utm_content=permalink utm_medium=user utm_source=reddit utm_name=frontpage), "trolling" might start out as fun or innocent enough, but my own history and childhood teaches me that what "trolling" unleashes can frequently be ***very*** difficult to put back in the bottle, and have very severe, unintended consequences - consequences that can survive generations.
Beyond this, I personally believe it is ludicrous for someone to see themselves or their identity as something that is ***beyond*** politics. All of us - being members of communities, neighborhoods, countries, families, etc. - have either been impacted, shaped, or participated [whether willingly or not] in some form of political project not necessarily thought of by themselves. For me, ***the personal is the political***, and I mean no offense by this, but I think it'd be deeply disingenuous of you to suggest none of your political views were previously formed on a level as deeply entwined as your identity or who you choose to be.
In a sense and possibly to his strategic and/or tactical credit, President Trump has identified this as a way to pull the country further into his camp: he identified "the establishment" as his enemy and the enemy of "the people" (language that personally disturbs me given my family history), which ***does*** have transpartisan appeal (President Trump himself praised Bernie Sanders for 'getting it right' this way, one reason why I refused to support Sanders).
I don't like the politics that is one premised on having enemies. To me, that is a politics of reaction - a politics of ***resentment***.
President Trump himself might not have wanted this, but he both inspired and ***inflamed*** a particular type of identity politics that cannot function without demonizing "multiculturalism" or others he deems as un-American. Many of his supporters support him ***because*** they pride their identities over others'. ***That*** is the right's version of ***"identity politics"***.
On the extreme left - the left that Sanders identified with - the essential premise of that political argument is that all issues of racial equality, gender equality, etc., are solely and exclusively derivative of an economic nationalism. Sanders' - and Sander's himself - might not have realized, but that is where they are more closely aligned with Trump's most extreme supporters. His economic populism and the economic nativism President Trump campaigned on are ***very, very*** similar things. The reason why is that both of these strands of thought ultimately come down to identity: ***Who was here first***, ***What was an acceptable community before***, and etc., etc., which is why self-described progressive Millennials nowadays who don't know history [do not understand Sanders' own opposition to open borders](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vf-k6qOfXz0), but what their older progressive cohort understood and sometimes even admired.
As a an American Jew who is very familiar with Jewish-American history, this allows me to understand what my well-meaning friends on the Left could not: moderates and centrists do not place themselves "in the middle" or "in the center" because they are soulless or without ideological fervor. They place themselves there because they know that ***both*** extremes - on the left ***and*** the right, aspire to a politics that is one premised on identity instead of politics that aspire to create or recreate a world that is ***comfortable with*** and ***not fearful*** of ***including others who do not share our particular identity*** in our own political communities. The idea that ***any*** politics that is one based purely on ideas and principles without any reference to identity - while at times admirable - has often never succeeded.
To me, this common - if not subconscious - strand of identity politics reveals itself when people who self-id as all political stripes actually are quite supportive of government-provided social safety-nets and welfare programs [***until they are asked if they support those programs if recipients are of another race or cultural identity***](https://eml.berkeley.edu/~saez/kuziemko-norton-saez-stantchevaAER15.pdf).
European Jewish emigres post-WWI and post-WWII - many of whom went from being socialist and communist to "neoconservative" or "Cold War liberals" - became disenchanted with the American Anti-War Left ***precisely because*** the American Left refused to see the failures and the totalitarian monstrosity of the USSR or of China, nor did they see the urgency of opposing Hitler, while they continued to vilify diversity issues as mere distractions on the way to a "communist utopia".
As secular American Jew from a family of Holocaust survivors, I inherited this history, and I inherited - so to speak - the "center" between Left and Right - just because Jews have known persecution from all sides, and so we are particularly weary when a politician becomes a leader of a country based on resentment towards immigrants.
S, whereas I find it a shame that politics cannot seem to fully escape the confines of particular identities, this is exactly why I ***choose*** to allow my American Jewish identity inform my political affiliations: As someone who wants to be able to speak with and hear the concerns of supporters of a man who politicize their ethnic pride and nativism, I cannot confine myself to abstract conversations about ideas, nor do I have time for the political circle-jerks you seem so intent on identifying me with.

Trolling can take on very real, tangible consequences, however.
Even if we give Trump the benefit of the doubt, and say that Trump unintentionally activated, mobilized [or "radicalized"] a whole bunch of angry, disconnected voters, it does not follow that Trump is not at fault for hateful or even violent behavior done in his name.
The fact is, he is now President of the entire country, and one subset of the populace [the stereotype of the "angry white male"] is increasingly violent to another subset [or a few others: minorities, immigrants, LGBTQ, "liberal snowflakes", etc.]. It's the President's ***job*** to at least ensure that this "trolling" does not go from being "a blast" to getting in the way of leading the country in a unified direction. In fact, he got that message when he was [made to tell his supporters to "stop it"](http://www.vox.com/2016/11/17/13639138/trump-hate-crimes-attacks-racism-xenophobia-islamophobia-schools), which I'd assume helped some but [not by much](https://www.buzzfeed.com/tasneemnashrulla/racist-incidents-after-trumps-victory?utm_term=.uhjv2Ba6a#.mu27XWzGz). So, assuming that Trump is very well-intentioned, "trolling" done in his name is largely his responsibility to stop. As a former businessman, he should be well-aware of how image and brand are essential to leadership.
As [RebasKradd](https://www.reddit.com/user/RebasKradd) says, these trolls are hurting the credibility of the conservative movement or the "saner" elements of his supporters. Trump won't be able to lead without that credibility, so it's his job to fix it. GOP leaders can't necessarily do this, as this Pew poll [reveals that more of his supporters trust him over them](http://www.people-press.org/2017/02/22/in-trump-era-what-partisans-want-from-their-congressional-leaders/). And it's ludicrous to think that the media, or the Democrats, or teachers, or therapists, should carry that load [or even that they can ***succeed***]. If Trump wants to be an effective leader, he cannot keep passing the buck and shrug off any responsibility. He cannot have large numbers of his supporters believing he's doing and saying one thing, while another part of of his supporters believes he's doing or saying something else. That does not make a good leader. How can he lead a country and while his own supporters don't know or don't agree on what he is asking of them? Leaders - at least those who want to lead a transpartisan or unified country - do not leave that kind of ambiguity out in the open.
As numerous reports by civil rights groups and nonpartisan think tanks document, such as [this one](http://bridge.georgetown.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/When-Islamophobia-Turns-Violent.pdf), that violent incidents towards minority communities have been committed, and the perpetrators consistently cite Trump, it at least stands to reason that Trump would decisively and directly say that he disavows any and all of this violent behavior done in his name. As said above, he did do this in one interview, even he would have to acknowledge that did not get to the more denser idiots (he has numerous times suggested that none of his supporters watch or trust the "mainstream media"). I would personally prefer him to use a few press conferences and even mailers, and his rally speeches, to tell the idiots to stop ruining his brand and let him and his saner allies and base lead the country.
It might arguably be too late, and I don't see why Trump can credibly say that he's completely without fault in any of this - he ***literally*** called many undocumented immigrants ["rapists," portraying a whole swath of undocumented Mexican immigrants as drug-dealing violent criminals](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2015/07/08/donald-trumps-false-comments-connecting-mexican-immigrants-and-crime/?utm_term=.090d828b82cf).
How can someone ***not*** understand that his supporters support him ***because they like what he says***? This seems to be pretty basic stuff: And I'm sorry, the excuse being thrown around that the unhinged subset of his base ["took him seriously, but not literally"](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/people-were-taking-trump-seriously-now-theyre-starting-to-take-him-literally-too/2017/01/25/dc86447e-e31d-11e6-ba11-63c4b4fb5a63_story.html) ***clearly*** [do not pay much attention](http://www.cnbc.com/2016/11/09/peter-thiel-perfectly-summed-up-donald-trump-in-one-paragraph.html) to violent incidents targeting the very same population Trump used to mobilize his base. The business leaders Trump says he wants to make deals with on behalf of the country [don't believe or take literally what he says or tweets](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-21/trump-was-taken-seriously-by-ceos-at-davos-but-not-literally). As left-of-center comedian John Oliver [summarized in one segment of his show](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xecEV4dSAXE), it's never a good sign when large pockets of the country don't know what Trump means when "he says words". Trump himself has mocked, ridiculed, and dismissed this confusion, [suggesting that it is ridiculous that the media takes everything that he says so seriously](http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/08/trump-mocks-media-for-thinking-he-means-anything-he-says.html).
I hope we can all put our previous partisan loyalties aside and agree on the basic idea that a leader should take his own words seriously and treat them with the gravity, clarity, sincerity, and weight his supporters and allies believe them to have. If he doesn't take this responsibility seriously, he is more suitable for private life.

My point is that the Founding Fathers did not want, nor would they legitimate, a system the allowed a demagogue into the WH. They did not want us to fight a Revolution only to have us embrace a wannabe king.
Repeat: They did not want a system - and warned against any system - that would allow Trump to happen.
I am not the one reaching here. The Founding Fathers would not settle for short-term expediency over bigger longer-term principles, and I'm surprised that we are letting ourselves be sucked into the same argument on popular [***populist***] expediency that the Founders saw as anathema to a free and well-governed society.
The entire reason why we transitioned from the Articles of Confederation to the Constitution was to prevent unpredictable, instantaneous disruption from spontaneously crashing the American consensus. To the Founders, change and political evolution were necessary. But they would also agree that once we had our initial American Revolution, political change in this country had to take on a less disruptive, more evolutionary character. As a student of American history, I believe that at this time, if the Founders saw Trump, they would see him as a more dangerous disruption than they see Clinton.
And as to the question of "maturity": The Founders ***debated*** and talked about the maturity or lack thereof of the electorate. That's the very question they were talking about when they were talking about [factions](http://tenthamendmentcenter.com/2015/09/04/federalist-10-the-power-of-factions/). This question of "immaturity" - or how I would exchange that with a more political term - ["populism"](http://thefederalist.com/2016/03/22/donald-trump-displays-the-perils-of-populism/) - was very much on the minds of the Founders. I would agree with that.
But they would say the onus of maturity should be shared by the electorate, and they would certainly see a Presidential campaign won on the insurrectionist manipulations of fear, anger, rage, and a vague, undirected desire for disruption [to be illegitimate and unworthy of office](http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/03/trump-founding-fathers-electoral-college-213777).
And like it or not, it looks like Trump's campaign was not seen as legitimate either by a credible majority of American voters either, so in actual fact, if the EC were to vote based on both popular will ***and*** its intended purpose, we'd still end up with Clinton.

So, I guess a lot of us here would implicitly acknowledge three things:
1) Our Founding Fathers rebelled against a foreign empire.
2. Putin, the head of a ***completely different country*** (Russia) helped install Trump through a [deliberate information warfare campaign](http://www.vox.com/world/2016/11/1/13487322/donald-trump-russia-agent-hack).
3. Trump [***cheered*** this on, to the point of ***asking them to do more of what they were doing***](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/28/us/politics/donald-trump-russia-clinton-emails.html).
If we can agree on all of these three things, we can thereby conclude two more things:
1) **Trump didn't care if he won an American election fairly**.
2) He went beyond the pale of American politics ***to a foreign entity*** to win.
Meaning:
3) ***He didn't win our American election by American rules***
So, the question I pose now: Why do we expect or want ***American rules*** set up for the ***American political system*** to protect and legitimate a cheater who won by ripping to shreds American rules [i.e., no foreign influence in our elections]?

And btw, are we forgetting that Trump essentially ***lied*** to the majority of his most fervent supporters among the Republican Party's base?
He definitely is not a Democrat - we all hopefully agree with that fact. The key now is to ***stop*** thinking of him as a ***Republican*** too. He is not a ***normal*** symptom of the two-party system, and certainly was never the type of figure our Founding Fathers would be comfortable with.
NeverTrump didn't start as a philosophically or politically binary movement. We should not end in binary thinking.
As far as I'm concerned now, mass demonstrations against the loser of the popular vote are pro-democracy demonstrations.

Also overlooked fact: The Founding Fathers never liked or wanted a two-party system. They didn't like parties. They only reluctantly condoned the formation of political parties as necessary evils.
In other wodrs, they wouldn't see Trump's win based on foreign influence and insurrectionary rhetoric as legitimate, and neither should we.
We already are seeing mass demonstrations.

This is an example of why a complete and absolute repudiation of Trump and his brand of politics is necessary on Election Day.
We need to "bury" Trump at the polls on November 8th, not only to preserve the legitimacy of American conservatism, but for American liberalism, for American politics, for the American election system, and for the American experiment itself.
No matter what side of the American political spectrum we identify with, this election puts America and its form of government and our way of life on the ballot. I think I can say without controversy here that we were never meant to become a sectarian, xenophobic police state. Even if there are some of us here who would rather minority groups ***assimilate*** into America's traditional way of life, I hope we can all agree that the American experiment was never, ever supposed to be about substituting ***assimilation*** of minority cultures for ***persecution*** of minority cultures.
Certainly, our country's Founders knew without any uncertainty that our political experiment was necessary ***in order to*** divorce the primitive, sectarian brutality of ***persecution*** from a more "enlightened" gradual and even incremental project of ***assimilation*** through compassionate civic dialogue. This is what the "American melting pot" has always been about: Everyone was welcome in our way of life and to add to our way of life, but in their own time. Our Founders ***knew*** the difference between **evolution** and **revolution**, and saw in their own experience that persecution ***always*** leads to disaffection and revolution, whereas respect for diversity will always lead us on the path of **evolution**.
Trump does not understand this about our American story, nor does he **accept** it. His is a [demonstrably nihilistic worldview where it is the natural order that the strong survive by eating the weak](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Yh0jAxOxGE). Survival is no longer by honest hard work or effort or civic life, but it is by ***chance***. Either you kill, or you ***are*** killed. In this view, only the "ruthless killers" are worthy of American citizenship - only the ruthless sharks who can kill off his competitors to get to the top of the pack. What this boils down to is a ***cultural eugenics*** - a perverted form of ***Social Darwinism***.- either you find your place ***immediately*** or you're out. No time for you to get on your feet. No patience for circumstance. No empathy or sympathy for the least of thee. If you break a sweat - well, there's no time for that; Trump's America will leave you behind. It doesn't matter if you ***aspire*** to live as a proud American - in the [inverted logic of Trump's cultural eugenics](http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/13/opinion/sunday/the-next-genocide.html), you either "have what it takes," or you don't. Worse still, in this worldview, diversity is seen as ***weakness***. Only the strong survive, and in Trump's dystopia, that means we all lose if America is still a diverse country.
In Trump's worldview, all of life is competition, and diversity just means a stronger culture has yet to kill off a weaker one. This is not patriotism, nor is it any form of nationalism. It is [***cultural, ethnic, and racial anarchism***](http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/09/hitler-holocaust-antisemitism-timothy-snyder/404260/).
And that brings us back to why Putin is paying trolls to sow discord in our election system, and is trying to radicalize hate and resentment in our society - he wants the world to see that America is just as prone to be taken over by monsters as any other society. Putin knows that his dictatorship does not have anywhere near the unanimous support of his own people - he knows that even if they vote for him, its because of the fear and uncertainty of the unknown. And this is why he supports Trump - if a democracy can be goaded into voting based on xenophobic lies and sectarian paranoia, and if fear and scarcity drives us instead of civic empathy, Putin wins. Putin wins on the domestic front, consolidating his support in the face of increasing peaceful dissent, and he wins on the world stage. If he succeeds in installing Trump as our President, he can show the whole world that democracy is merely a mask for anarchy and chaos. And thus, Trump wil be his message to the world: This is what democracy brings you: ***Fear, violence, chaos, anarchy, and hate.***
This is why defeating Trump is not only a Democrat issue, a Republican issue, a Libertarian issue, a Green Party issue, a Constitution Party issue - it is an ***American issue***. And Im not saying its enough to ***beat*** Trump. We have to ***bury*** him. We have to show the world, and those among us who have let ourselves be brainwashed by him, that part of American pride is that we do not tolerate his politics of hate or his politics of fear. We do not accept that America is a hunting ground where the wolves hunt for the lambs, nor can we accept America being made into a [WWE wrestling match in which the strongest narcissist survives by humiliating the weak](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ypOwLUMUHw0).
This election is a transpartisan, American election. Hate and fear and prejudice have always been with us. But the point of democracy, ***particularly our democracy***, is to show the world [***and ourselves***] that elections can bring policies that give us the civic space needed to help ***solve*** those fears and those prejudices. Trump sees fear and prejudice as a motivating force - and his answer is that we win when we kill and destroy all that we fear and all that we hate.
Trump doesnt want us to see ourselves as ***Americans***. If we see ourselves as Americans, committed to living in and building a country together, Trump loses. Contrary to Trumps surrogates in the media, most Democrats dont ***hate*** Republicans, most Republicans dont ***fear*** Democrats, Northerners dont ***look down on and vilify*** Southerners, etc. But Trump ***needs*** us to believe this if he is to win. He ***needs*** us to see the world just like he does - a world where anarchy and ruthless competition and chaos is the natural state of things, where a more gradual democratic evolutionism is replaced by a dystopic hybrid between cultural anarchy and [political authoritarianism, where even a lifelong patriot and veterans integrity is questioned because his captivity signals weakness](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5YU9djt_CQM). Trump wins if more American voters than not allow themselves to believe that honest political disagreement or even peaceful, nonviolent dissent equals a violent betrayal that cannot be solved through the evolutionary project of civic life or public dialogue, or even the dignity of guaranteed citizenship. Trump wins if we allow ourselves to adopt a regressive, immature view of disagreement - if you dont agree with me, youre ***a traitor*** and you are not ***an American***. Thats why birthright citizenship is so important - an American child who grows up here and lives here should feel safe enough to tell her or his government or politicians what they do or do not agree with, without any fear that their citizenship will be stripped from them for speaking up or exercising their conscience.
Ever since our Founding, this has been our Democratic experiment, It was not always perfect, but it always ***aspired to be***. And thats the difference between how our Founders saw this countrys potential and how Trump sees this country - unlike our politics of ***aspiration***, his is a politics - and a ***culture*** - of fear and of scarcity. In his small mind, diversity and disagreement cannot ever exist ***because we lose our chance to eat***. Were all just basically hunter-gatherers back in anarchic times without nations. Were either the hunters or the hunted.
And if Trump wins, this ideology of depravity and this anarchic fear of scarcity replaces the role of public reason and patient and compassionate dialogue as the driving force of our politics. ***And our American democratic experiment dies***. A country cannot stand on persecution. A country cannot stand, nor survive, by characterizing diversity or disagreement as weakness or ***betrayal***. In America, we embrace diversity. We embrace it because were strong enough to do so without upending our own way of life. Were strong enough to learn from one another and to move the country forward by forming new consensus through dialogue and respectful debate.
Trump does not understand this, and by all appearances, he ***does not want to understand this*** and even ***rejects what little of it he does understand***. This is why, as a free, strong, and open society, we ***must reject him***. But we must reject him as ***Americans*** - not Democrats, Republicans, Libertarians, Socialists, Greens, etc. **As Americans.**
And come November 9th and the days and weeks and months and years after election day, the test of our success will be how long we can stay together as **Americans**, and continue being a culture of strength through diversity.

Clinton, meanwhile, has exhibited ***both*** a libertarian-leaning understanding of the importance of fiscal responsibility, balancing the budget, and of non-government intervention in social lives (***she is socially liberal and more fiscally conservative than Trump***). In other words, she is closer to a ***classical liberal*** than Trump ever was or can be, and classical liberalism is ***closer*** to contemporary libertarian philosophy than right-wing, ethnic, economic populism.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio solicits the opinions of many confidants before making decisions. Then he often disregards their counsel, forging ahead in ways that his inner circle sometimes describes as politically imprudent.
This year, Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat, has sought to curtail the horse-carriage industry, escalated a fight with one of the citys most prominent newspapers and declined to release his emails with five longtime advisers who work outside of governmentall positions that many in his inner circle oppose.
If hes convinced hes making the right decision, he wont back down, said Karen Hinton, a former press secretary to Mr. de Blasio who left the administration in June. Depending on your perspective, its his best or worst quality.
According to people close to him, Mr. de Blasio, 55 years old, often bristles when aides disagree with him, and some of them said they have never worked for a more stubborn person. Mr. de Blasio has told those close to him that they are giving him conventional wisdom or listening too much to his critics, these people said, and should instead focus on the mission, or what he calls his administrations work.
Eric Phillips, who succeeded Ms. Hinton as press secretary, said Mr. de Blasio has a clear-eyed vision to improve the city.
He wont compromise that mission by conforming to some outdated or past mayors concept of the job, Mr. Phillips said.
Earlier this month, Mr. de Blasio called the New York Post a right-wing rag and a negative presence in our city and declined to answer questions from the news outlet. Some of his advisers have winced at the fight, saying they dont believe Mr. de Blasio benefits from attacking the newspaper.
The mayor has told allies that print media is fading, social media is rising and that people will agree with his criticisms of the Post. Asked for comment, a spokeswoman for the Post referred to the newspapers front page earlier this month depicting the mayor as a baby crying in a high chair. The Post and The Wall Street Journal are both owned by News Corp.
In September, two media outlets sued the mayor over his administrations decision not to release emails between Mr. de Blasio and five advisers.
People close to Mr. de Blasio have recommended releasing the emails, but the mayor has doubled down, with aides and lawyers huddling at Gracie Mansion earlier this month to discuss fighting the lawsuit.
The mayors trip last winter to Iowa to campaign for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, even though he wasnt invited by Mrs. Clintons campaign, was widely opposed by his advisers. Many of the mayors allies disagreed with Mr. de Blasios 2015 decision to delay his endorsement of Mrs. Clinton for six months.
Mr. de Blasio told his allies he wanted to push Mrs. Clinton to the left and he coveted a bigger voice on the national stage. He said this month he had no regrets, even as leaked emails from Mrs. Clintons campaign showed some of her aides were frustrated by the mayors actions.
This year, the mayors aides mocked Mr. de Blasios proposed limits on horse carriages, according to emails reviewed by the Journal. Even after the proposal fell through, Mr. de Blasio told aides he wanted to try to revive it, drawing resistance from some of his staff.
On many mornings, Mr. de Blasio travels from Gracie Mansion on Manhattans Upper East Side to a gym in Brooklyn, a 12-mile midmorning trip that has attracted protests and has become the subject of jokes around City Hall among people close to the mayor. Mr. de Blasio has said he has no plans to change his gym routine.
Those close to Mr. de Blasio said the mayors governing approach is deeply rooted in his experience working for former Mayor David Dinkins in the 1990s and his own come-from-behind victory in the 2013 mayoral race.
Mr. de Blasio believes Mr. Dinkins was unfairly attacked as a liberal Democrat. In 2013, as a candidate for mayor, Mr. de Blasio shunned all sorts of advice as he floundered early on in the polls during the primary.
Bill Hyers, Mr. de Blasios 2013 campaign manager, said many people urged Mr. de Blasio to change course during the primary. But Mr. de Blasio stuck to his guns, stayed disciplined on the change and inequality message and ultimately won, Mr. Hyers said.
To the dismay of some close to him, the mayor has said he isnt interested in attending events his predecessors have traditionally gone tosuch as parties in Manhattanif he doesnt believe they jibe with his ideological mission or if he disagrees with their corporate sponsors.
Whether you like the mayors politics or not, said Mr. Phillips, the mayors spokesman, we think New Yorkers respect that hes not trying to be anything other than himself.

You owe it to your fellow citizens who are most ideologically aligned with you to amplify their votes
The keyword above is ***amplify*** and if you agree that Stein would replicate her past electoral successes, there's very little possibility that you ensure the outcome that your friends' votes would be ***amplified*** in any meaningful or consequential way by refusing to vote for Clinton.

Yes, because this is the outcome of any general election in this country.
I would vote in favor of the policies I actually want, instead. If everyone did that, the two deeply unfavorable parties would lose every election.
If you agree that Trump is beating Clinton in the polls, that means the majority would prefer her over Trump. And no, it is not true that both are hated in equal numbers. If that were true, and if you simultaneously want to insist that Jill Stein still can win, we should be able to see shifts in support between Clinton and Stein such that they flip their electoral positions, or at the very least, she and Trump would flip electoral positions, which they are not.
In other words, if we stick to ***realistic*** probabilistic calculations, even if we both agree that Stein would be able to switch electoral positions with Trump [which she has not so far], you'd have to agree that Clinton would ***still be doing better than Stein is***.
And this brings us to exactly where we are in chronological order:
1) Clinton 2) Trump 3) Johnson 4) Stein
If you insist that Stein is more popular the Clinton, Stein would have to move from position 4, pass Johnson, pass Trump, and then at least move within striking distance of Clinton. In other words, Stein would have to garner enough votes away from ***both** Trump ***and*** Johnson to even come ***close*** to Clinton's electoral position.
And you cannot conclude that she's more popular than Clinton if she's losing to ***both*** Trump ***and*** Johnson. You cannot say that an electoral distance between number 1 and number 4 has nothing to do with policy preference.
In other words, if you would agree that at least some of the difference between the electoral positions between Trump and Clinton have to do with policy preferences, it is likely that if you would agree that Trump is farther away from you on the political spectrum than Clinton is, it would be ***necessarily*** true that you would ***rather*** Clinton become President than Trump.
If you prefer ***Johnson*** to Clinton, that does not change the electoral positions, because Johnson would still be one electoral position ***above*** Stein, which is deceptive since we're not counting the large ***vote share*** Johnson is leading Stein with. So voting for Johnson still does not switch Johnson's electoral position with Clinton's, let alone invert their voting shares.
So, to go back to an argument based on the candidates' ***actual positions*** and assuming you're not so brazen as to write off the feelings of an entire sub-constituency, Clinton would still be beating Trump, and that ***necessitates*** her winning greater voter share than Stein. In [***no** current polls](http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/us/general_election_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson_vs_stein-5952.html#polls) is Stein beating Trump **or** Johnson. At the very least, if you were correct in your implication that Trump and Clinton are hated ***equally***, Stein should at least have ***more*** of a vote share to Johnson's and thus threaten the vote share of Trump's. But Stein is not doing that.
Like it or not, only one person can be President, and this means Stein would have to take ***both*** voting shares of Trump's ***and*** Johnson's to have a shot at beating out Clinton for the Presidency.
Argue all you like, but electorally, whether Johnson and Trump's positions are inverted with Stein's Clinton is still winning.
And in fact, if Stein ***were not*** in the race, Clinton would be winning by larger margins over Trump, because by probabilistic reasoning [assuming that Johnson would be the second choice for Stein supporters], Johnson would ***still*** not be beating Clinton even with Stein's cumulative share.
So, in other words, not only would your assertion that Trump and Clinton are equally hated to be ***reductive***, it also would more probably than not be ***offensive*** to a whole bunch of voters who actually like Clinton and/or her policies. (Look at the same collection of polls I linked to above).
I myself happen to like both Clinton and her policies, **beyond** any pragmatic consideration ***out of the candidates we have*** (I would have preferred Elizabeth Warren and I was heavily involved with a draft campaign for her before the primaries officially started).
But, if you want to shift the conversation from ***electorally probabilistic arguments*** to arguments of ***policy***, I'd be more than happy to. Just know that it is generally the case that policy positions are more correlative with popularity/likeability and vote share/electoral positions. Which would mean that more voters ***like*** more of Clinton's policies than ***both*** Trump's ***and*** Johnson's.

During October 2013, the month after lane closures at the George Washington Bridge choked Fort Lee, N.J. with five days of traffic, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie discussed the fallout from the closures, the governments star witness testified Tuesday.
He testified that the two governors agreed that a report would be issued saying the lane closures were a traffic study, and the New Jersey side of the Port Authority would accept responsibility. Then, he testified, the New York head of the agency would sign off on it.
My understanding at the time was that that would put an end of this issue, David Wildstein, a former Port Authority official, said in U.S. District Court in Newark.
A spokesman for Mr. Cuomo attacked the testimony, saying the governor had played a positive role in the episode. It was our executive director who blew the whistle and ordered the bridge reopened. To be clear, no such conversation between the governors happened, in fact no report of any kind was ever done, and whatever the admitted bridgegate architect thought or dreamt about New Yorks involvement has no basis in fact.
A spokesman for Mr. Christie had no immediate comment.
The Wall Street Journal previously reported that the governors spoke privately in early December 2013, when Mr. Christie, a Republican, called Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, to express frustration that Port Authority Executive Director Patrick Foye had been pushing too hard to investigate the lane closures.
Following that story, Mr. Cuomo, publicly backed Mr. Christies traffic study explanation for the closures, saying at a news conference that Im sure it is as Gov. Christie says it is. At the time, Mr. Foye, a Cuomo appointee, had already testified under oath that no such study existed.
On Tuesday, attorney Michael Critchley, who represents defendant Bridget Kelly, continued his cross examination of Mr. Wildstein by focusing on the effort to contain the fallout from the closures, which he said ensnared high-level officials in the governors officebut not his client.
Ms. Kelly, a former deputy chief of staff to Mr. Christie, and Bill Baroni, former deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, are on trial for allegedly orchestrating a scheme to cause traffic jams in Fort Lee. N.J., to punish the boroughs Democratic mayor for not endorsing Mr. Christie, a Republican.
Mr. Christie hasnt been charged with wrongdoing and has repeatedly denied knowledge of the lane closures before and while they occurred.
During cross examination, Mr. Critchley portrayed the time after the lane closures as one in which high-level staffers in the governors office were trying to contain political fallout from the closures.
Asked about the plan regarding the report, Mr. Wildstein said he understood that Mr. Foye, the Port Authoritys executive director, would sign off on it.
You felt that Foye would sign it because you believed Albany had told Foye to, quote, lay off Christie, Mr. Critchley argued. Mr. Wildstein said that was his understanding, based upon conversations with David Samson, the Port Authoritys former chairman, and Mr. Baroni.
Mr. Foye has said he wont comment during the trial, and a Port Authority spokesman declined to comment on the substance of Mr. Wildsteins testimony.
Mr. Critchley also focused his questioning Tuesday on the preparation for Mr. Baronis November 2013 testimony defending the lane closure to a legislative committee in Trenton. During that testimony, Mr. Baroni said the closures were a traffic study. Mr. Wildstein has testified this was a cover story.
According to Mr. Wildstein, those involved planning the report claiming there was a traffic study included aides to both Port Authority officials appointed by Mr. Christie and aides to Mr. Christie himself.
Ms. Kelly had nothing to do with that report? Mr. Critchley, the defense attorney who represents Ms. Kelly, asked.
No sir, she didnt, Mr. Wildstein said.
One text message shown in court was from a policy adviser at the Port Authority at the time. Handed off the packet to Nicole a few minutes ago, read the text, which was sent on Nov. 25, 2013. The package, Mr. Wildstein said, referred to the report.
The governors office said they didnt want any emails? the attorney asked.
That was correct, Mr. Wildstein said.

Abstract:
Big data refers to the ability to gather large volumes of data, often from multiple sources, and with it produce new kinds of observations, measurements and predictions. Commercial applications of big data deserve ongoing scrutiny given the speed at which both the technology and business practices are evolving. One of the many questions raised by big data is whether companies will use the information they harvest to more effectively charge different prices to different customers, a practice that economists call price discrimination. Economics suggests that many forms of differential pricing, such as senior citizen discounts at the box office or tiered pricing for air travel, can be good for both businesses and consumers. However, the combination of differential pricing and big data raises concerns that some consumers can be made worse off, and have very little knowledge why. This report finds that many companies already use big data for targeted marketing, and some are experimenting with personalized pricing, though examples of personalized pricing remain fairly limited. While substantive concerns about differential pricing in the age of big data remain, many of them can be addressed by enforcing existing antidiscrimination, privacy, and consumer protection laws. In addition, providing consumers with increased transparency into how companies use and trade their data would promote more competition and better informed consumer choice.

Essentially, people only want to live with like-minded individuals, so cities are built around those personal lifestyle, social, and political preferences.
The greater theme of Bill Bishop's book is how the built environment goes hand in hand with the re-entrenchment of our "echo chambers," where we are increasingly siloed from those who live differently than us. In the Weimar Republic, the Communists thought the same way, and decided the Social Democrats were too centrist. Together, they had a winning coalition. But then, the Communists decided the Social Democrats were not pure enough for their political revolution.
So, instead of working on building a coalition where they had a definite shot at an influence, the Communists decided to withdraw from electoral politics. For them, letting the system blow up was preferable than being a a member of a ruling coalition with Social Democrats.
You know what happened after they abandoned that coalition? Nazi Germany. [The end result of their "political revolution" was the murder of 6 million people.](http://prospect.org/article/bernie-hillary-and-ghost-ernst-thalmann)
If you think Sanders has a better shot at pushing Trump, you need to reassess your understanding of political history.

No, you seem to be missing my point.
No matter how much you disagree with Clinton, or are disappointed in President Obama, you'd never hear them campaign on ideology tests, or xenophobia, or nativism, or the incitement of violence.
And so, that's also a ***huge*** difference for this very simple reason: ***racist assholes will see an avowed racist become president, and they will start thinking that you can be an open racist and still be successful in national politics***.
One case in point: David Duke, ex-KKK Grand Wizard, explicitly said that Trump's success on the campaign trail inspired him to get back into politics.
So, you see, the distinction ***is*** the point. Electing Trump means showing his racist supporters that it's OK to campaign openly on hate, fear, bigotry, and misogyny. By allowing Trump to be elected, you're in effect telling them ***"it's OK to be racist."*** You can add on "... as long as you're not a neoliberal corporatist" to that all you want, but you'll still be sending a very clear message that this country would rather have an open racist as president [who very explicitly said that lower-income communities of color should be policed even more] than a woman who I hope you admit at the ***very least*** would never think of using the campaign trail to incite hate crimes or transphobic violence.
I assume you are familiar with the importance of symbolism in politics since you refuse to vote for the Democrat in the race, so you must realize that this election is about more than policy. ***It's the culture and values we want to teach our kids and their generation to take into to their own future***.
The Supreme Court has done more to shape our legal, social, and political culture than arguably any other institution in our country. I'm not willing to let Trump shape that for 50 years [at the very least].
So, you may rightfully say racism and hate have always been with us, but pointing out the distinction between Trump and his supporters is ***exactly*** my point: electing Trump will say to ***them*** that they don't hide their racism, or use the excuse of any extrajudicial for of justice, etc. By electing Trump, you're telling entire communities that their prejudices are acceptable in our social, legal, and moral systems. You're telling entire transphobic states in the South that more of their businesses will be protected if they discriminate. You're telling police departments that police brutality can be justified because their President Trump [who you were OK with getting into office], said that "the problem" with police brutality in lower-income communities of color was because of ***under-policing*** and ***not enough harassment***.
I'm unwilling to send that message to his supporters. There's a difference between institutional racism and out-and-out racism. The former is covered-up and hidden. It's concealed. And because of that, it can be exposed for its hypocrisy and fought, and can be dragged into the light to be publicly shamed. ***Out-and-out racism*** is when a candidate doesn't even ***hide*** the fact that he inspires anti-immigrant violence, only calling them ***'crimes of passion'***. there's not light to drag him into to publicly shame him. And that means his supporters won't be afraid either of any such publicity. On the contrary, they'll start thinking that racism should be openly celebrated.
[If Trump becomes President, racism won't have to hide behind institutions any longer.] (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w6l0Qb6Xlaw)
That's when we go from situations like laughing at the insurgent Nazi Party as clowns to the collapse of the Weimar Republic into Nazi Germany.
And it sends a big fuck you message to our entire country as you destroy your own cause.

Tom Perez would be an amazing pick.
He's not only super-qualified, but can kneecap Trump on his 'whites-only' "law and order" image. Perez going down to Florida to meet with Trayvon Martin's family when he headed DOJ's investigation, getting a police chief fired for failing his duties, would be a powerful story when anxieties over police brutality and extrajudicial vigilantism are still fresh.
On top of bringing down Joe Arpaio under [Bill] Clinton's Crime Bill and the CRA, and then fighting Voter ID in SC and Texas? That would be the end of Trump.
And it would be a hugely important symbolic victory to retake "law and order" from a blandly white ticket headed by a [suspected] racist.
A Perez pick would not only cement the bridge between Obama and the ticket and the future admin, but can remind everyone that being tough on law and order issues can also mean being pro-labor and pro-civil rights, and being strongly for immigration. Would be a an incredibly important story to tell.
Picking him would also have the added bonus of tying gun violence to issues of racial justice and police brutality.
And it would be a stunningly powerful image to see Tom Perez and Sybrina Fulton (mother of Trayvon Martin) on the stage together at the DNC. Would send us all a very important wake up call to carry into future generations.

People in this country - especially on the self-identified "Progressive Left" - forget that the example of a "political revolution" they hold so dear - essentially [was made possible only through an ethnic statist compromise](http://www.historyandpolicy.org/policy-papers/papers/when-affirmative-action-was-white}. FDR still had out-and-out xenophobes in his party leftover from past electoral realignments, and he couldn't pass most if not all of his central New Deal programs without them. So, he had to make concessions to the cultural populists on ***both*** sides of the aisle [after he realized he was politically-outnumbered](http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704631504575532371905049074).
One supporter of Bernie or Bust also gave me the example of LBJ''s Great Society as an example of a successful political revolution. Unfortunately, such a claim reveals historical ignorance as well [assuming that Bernie's supporters do not want ethnic statism]. One of LBJ's closest aides wrote a memoir reflecting on the administration's [failure to upend entrenched ethnic statism in his own party](http://sites.middlebury.edu/presidentialpower/tag/harry-mcpherson/). In his book on post-Civil Rights regulatory agencies, Hanes Walton [documents how these agencies enforcement and compliance capabilities were utterly laughable](http://www.sunypress.edu/p-893-when-the-marching-stopped.aspx).
Walton doesn't go on to make these speculations, but I believe this effectively buffered the institutionalized ethnic statism of the Democratic Party - and I think this very same ethnic statism leads to the predominantly white supporters of Bernie Or Bust throwing temper tantrums that the economy is "rigged" against them, while an increasing amount of [polls] (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/for-blacks-and-hispanics-the-economic-glass-is-still-half-full/) show a [more positive economic outlook among communities of color](http://www.pewhispanic.org/2016/06/08/latinos-increasingly-confident-in-personal-finances-see-better-economic-times-ahead/) as we come out of the last recession.
I don't believe this is an historical coincidence. I believe Bernie Sanders was able to tap into the anxieties and resentments of white kids who see that their white parents were able to benefit from an [unidentified] white statism, while POC communities who are unfortunately on aggregate used to getting a smaller piece of the economic pie are "more optimistic" because they are seeing that their kids and grand-kids have more opportunities too rise up the economic ladder than they did, and these younger generations in POC communities are told this through family stories or shown this by the wealth or income gaps between them and their parent and grandparents.
Bernie's supporters are used to benefiting from the racialized economic rents of the New Deal, or at least used to seeing their parents and grandparents benefit from these institutionalized rents.
So, in summation, both Bernie and his supporters remember a closed-border white statist utopia where they didn't have to compete on the free/open market with as many skilled immigrants, and getting back to that is their idea of revolution.
Even if they don't identify the goal as ethnic statism, it is. They just might not recognize that that is what they want, but that doesn't change the fact that Bernie's appeal is based on statist disenfranchisement.

"Bernie or Bust" is deeply self-defeatist.
If we look at electoral history and the history of GOTV strategy, both Parties move to where voters are. They shift their efforts to where they can find voters.
In other words, "Bernie or Bust," by not voting in the presidential election if Hillary is the nominee, is not where the voters are because they would ensure that they themselves are not counted among the people most engaged and who vote.
Put more simply, "Bernie or Bust" would only ensure that progressive leaders like Bernie are made even more irrelevant and marginal to the DNC's electoral, political, and GOTV strategies..
This outcome wouldn't simply be because the DNC is somehow being nefarious; Bernie supporters who don't vote will just be making themselves invisible to the Party and the political establishment. The DNC won't know where to look for those voters in the next election cycle, and they wouldn't know how to engage that crowd.
Also, according to exit polls so far in local races, there is a statistically-significant correlation between Sanders voters and nonvoters in state and local elections. If the "Bernie or Bust" crowd truly want a political revolution, the answer is not to sit out of the election - it is to vote in ALL races no matter how insignificant they seem to be. If the more Sanders supporters elect pro-Sanders candidates to Congress and other local offices, Hillary and/or other center-left Democrats can be given a chance to move left without becoming politically and electorally vulnerable.
Thus, Sanders' "revolution" would have a better shot at succeeding in the election booth rather than not voting in protest.

You might want to check out Nootropics Depot. I am also relatively new to the noot world, but ever since my intro to this world, I have become very fond of ND. http://nootropicsdepot.com/
My stack largely is oriented towards improving abstract and visual-spatial reasoning, so this list might help.
Adrafinil, Aniracetam, Caffeine + L-Theanine, Centrophenoxine, Oxiracetam, Noopept, Phenylpiracetam, and Teacrine.
However, what I would call my "base stack" does not include the Caffeine + L-Theanine or the Teacrine. I've added those more recently after the others, but don't know yet if I'll keep them in my stack.
In my understanding, those two noots are the more naturalistic noots in my stack, and so a lot of the newer members of the noot community decide to start with those and gradually work up towards the more synthetic/experimental/investigational noots. Some, like a few friends of mine, opt to stay with these kinds of noots, citing some concerns over perceived risk.
I personally don't mind any of the risk factors [I haven't encountered any noticeable issues], but if you also share these concerns, I think you might want to start out gradually with the natural noots first.
Even though I don't think there is any base for concern around taking the more synthetic noots, you are theoretically more liable to **psych yourself out** and have a negative **placebo** effects. So, if you are currently in this head-space, I'd suggest **starting off slow** so you don't trick your own brain/mind into magnifying any bad side-effects. The placebo effect, as you know, can be **incredibly powerful**, so even if there is **absolutely nothing** there, the expectation that something bad will happen **itself** will bias your experience.
This is most of the stack I am currently using, and Nootropics Depot is a great place to get these from. They have really awesome customer service as well, so you can totally ask them for any other pointers or suggestions.

This paper is a fascinating reappraisal of stress and anxiety.
Essentially, the study concluded that people who associate stress with something bad had worse health outcomes [physiological, neurological, and psychological] than people who considered stress as a helpful indicator that a behavior or activity will result in negative consequences.
In other words, participants who view stress as a "friend" who politely suggests to them that they do something different or to avoid something bad is more likely to have healthier outcomes than participants who saw stress itself as something bad and something to avoid.

This paper is very interesting. To paraphrase, the study observes that having a dense, intimate social network in which close, face-to-face contact is frequent, this reduces both stress and the risks of premature mortality.
The study also concludes that if the act of giving, altruism, or mutual support are frequent themes in such intimate relationships, this also reduces stress and the risk of premature mortality to a notable degree.
The authors conclude with policy proposals of encouraging communal mutual support and one-on-one supportive and mentoring relationships.
I should note that by 'intimacy', I do not only mean it in a romantic or sexual context.
I did not make any such assumption. I don't think the article did either.

Then, it's my mistake. I understood you to say you only vote when you think it's necessary to influence politician's decisions.
Hence, I assumed you meant that once your policy preferences are given priority among politicians and policymakers, you don't see voting as a necessity.
Totally my mistake.

And I would reply to that, as I did in my previous response, that voting 'when necessary' to influence elections (I take this to means you don't vote when you don't think it's necessary and/or your ideals are not under threat) can - according to most of political history - be misguided.
Parties need to constantly hear from their voters to know if the direction they are going in is the voters' direction. If they don't constantly hear from certain demos of voters, they start looking for other demos who vote more reliably and consistently.
Conversely, back to your initial idea that the youth vote lost faith with the DNC due to unpalatable policy shifts and the absence of voter outreach, too many voters only vote due to perceived necessity in presidential elections to a significantly greater degree than in local and state elections.
Unfortunately, too many voters [you're likely not included] seems to have forgotten their civics and their Constitution, particularly the Separation of Powers.
If voters vote only due to necessity, *Congress* [and probably the *Presidency*] will only act out of necessity - their behavior in other words will reflect what their voters want and what they view necessary. Congress only sees issues as necessary if voters see them as necessary - that's how popular representation, Congressional behavior, and executive (Presidential) behavior works.
If voters don't see the need to consistently vote or support a party's agenda because they perceive that their ideals are sufficiently entrenched in the Party and their ideology is not under threat, the Party will inevitably decide to look where they get more consistent, reliable voter feedback.
Example: lots of Democratic voters loved Obamacare when it was introduced and a few months in, but voters became complacent and stopped seeing a need to sustain these policy changes. The 2010 and 2014 elections are two of the more recent examples of this.
Three underlying assumptions that voters who vote only due to "necessity" seem to take as givens: 1. Political parties are monolithic, 2. Because of this, Parties have a monopoly over policy decisions/policy agendas. 3. Thus, once voters help secure an agenda, politicians have a mandate that is effective until he or she gets out of office.

Unfortunately, voting only for "necessity" is not enough to induce either Party to mobilize voters in your demographics or geographical area.
I've long had a semi-beef with fellow progressives on this very issue. For example, many Sanders supporters say they won't support Clinton if she is the nominee.
Their arguments largely are to the effect that letting the GOP nominee win will convince the DNC to start supporting candidates more progressive than Clinton in future election cycles.
As a long-time political observer and as a political scientist and historian, this is a glaring mistake in political and electoral causation.
Political parties move to where **voters are**. Conversely, where there are no voters, **there is no Party**.
Generally, it is an assumption that smart electoral practice demands that parties go where the voters are, because otherwise, they are wasting their own time and their bases' time. And if Parties waste their bases' time, Parties risk losing the voters they have. And those voters that the Democratic Party will be worried about losing won't be progressives as long as they don't vote.
Political parties allocate more delegates and superdelegates to high-turnout states. In this case, if voter turnout is depressed in blue states relative to purple or even red states, delegates are allocated to where more viable (i.e., more conservative or centrist) Democrats are.
In fact, one of the reasons the delegate and superdelegate system was created was to ensure that if depressed voter turnout is low enough to allow a totally unpopular or unelectable or destructive candidate to win due to miserable turnout numbers [i.e., Trump], the delegates would step in to offset the low voter turnout.
In the Bernie vs. Hillary example, if his supporters *don't* vote for a Democratic nominee who is decidedly **not** the most conservative Democrat ideologically, not only will the DNC look for someone more conservative than Hillary to support, but Sanders' own supporters will have misguidedly caused figures similar to Bernie irrelevant and marginal to the Party's electoral calculus.
Political parties - particularly the DNC - are more responsive to voters than many people seem to realize. And one of the larger ways they are able to "read" the electorate and the country's mood is through voter turnout. Thus, if only conservative or moderate Democrats vote, and progressives don not, parties have no choice but to listen to the conservative/moderate Democrat vote.
